1.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
1.title: "The Acoustics of Manga : Narrative Erotics and the Visual Presence of Sound"
1.author: Robert S
1.appears_in: Petersen. p. 578-590 in International Journal of Comic Art, v. 9, no. 1 (Spring 2007).

2.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
2.title: "Alice au Pays des Cases : la Bande Dessinée Japonaise pour Filles et Pour Femmes"
2.author: Béatrice Maréchal
2.appears_in: p. 66-73 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 6 (Jan. 2001).
notes: Begins: "L'introduction à la brochure de l'exposition sur les bandes dessinées pour filles qui s'est tenue au musée de Kawasaki en août et september 1998, s'ouvrait par la question: 'Que sont les bandes dessinées pour filles?' Quel est, en effet, l'élément déterminant, du sexe du personnage principal ou du label 'bande dessinée pour filles' porté en couverture d'un magazine?"

English summary (from p. 151): "Alice in the Land of Vignettes : Japanese Comics for Girls and Ladies. In Japan, girls' and women's comics constitute two very large parts of the market and are largely the work of feminine authors. Béatrice Maréchal presents the different trends that traverse this romantic world."

13.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
13.title: "Conversation avec Boilet et Taniguchi"
13.author: Julien Bastide
13.appears_in: p. 54-61 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 10 (Apr. 2004).
notes: Begins: "Le premier est le seul auteur de bandes dessinées français ayant réussi à s'implanter au Japon; le second est l'auteur japonais que tout le monde s'arrache depuis le succès en France de Quartier lointain, Alph'art du meilleur scénario au Festival d'Angoulême 2003. Frédéric Boilet et Jirô Taniguchi se sont rencontrés en 1991, et n'ont depuis cessé de travailler ensemble, oeuvrant pour une meilleure connaissance de la bande dessinée japonaise en France, et réciproquement. Retour sur douze ans d'amitié et deux collaborations."

English summary (from p. 127): "Conversation with Boilet and Taniguchi. One is the only French author to have succeeded in establishing a following in Japan; the other a Japanese author in great demand since the success of Quartier Lointain. Frédéric Boilet and Jirô Taniguchi met in 1991 and have since constantly worked to make French comics better known in Japan and vice versa. Julien Bastide orchestrates a dialogue between the two, going back over twelve years of friendship and two co-signed works."

18.title: Fresh Pulp : Dispatches from Japanese Pop Culture Front

19.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
19.title: "Garo, Magazine Rebelle"
19.author: Béatrice Maréchal
19.appears_in: p. 48-53 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 10 (Apr. 2004).
notes: Begins: "Le nome de Garo évoque un mensuel de bandes dessinées qui a ouvert de nouveaux champs de création, révélé des artistes marquants, intéressé à ce média des lecteurs d'autres horizons. On a pu être garo-ha (tendence Garo), de même qu'on a pu dire d'une oeuvre qu'elle est garo-téki ('garotique'). Il s'agit donc d'un magazine à 'forte personnalité', qui a joué un rôle indéniable. L'héritage qu'il laisse au neuvième art continue d'habiter les consciences."

English summary (from p. 126): "Garo, a Rebel Magazine. From 1964 to 2002, the magazine Garo was a showcase for quality Japanese graphic novel-style mangas. It discovered quantities of new creators and popularized new genres such as 'comics of the self'. Béatrice Maréchal describes the different phases of this adventure and evaluates the heritage it has left to manga."

85.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Dictionaries.
85.title: Manga : the Complete Guide
85.author: Jason Thompson.
notes: Summary: "Whether you're new to the world of manga-style graphic novels or a longtime reader on the lookout for the next hot series, here's a comprehensive guide to the wide, wonderful world of Japanese comics! Includes incisive, full-length reviews of stories and artwork; titles rated from zero to four stars; guidelines for age-appropriateness; profiles of the biggest names in manga, including CLAMP, Osamu Tezuka, Rumiko Takahashi, and many others; the facts on the many kinds of manga; an overview of the manga industry and its history; and a detailed bibliography and a glossary of manga terms."

130.title: "Manga-Comics for Beginners?"

notes: Letter requesting a column on Japanese comics on the order of Bart Beaty's "Euro-Comics for Beginners."

131.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Miscellanea.
131.title: The Manga Cookbook
131.author: presented by the Manga University Culinary Institute, with recipes by Yoko Ishihara ; illustrated by Chihiro Hattori.
notes: "Reading manga sure can make a person hungry! Food appears frequently in Japanese comics, but what exactly is it that the characters are eating? Introducing The Manga Cookbook, an illustrated step-by-step guide to preparing simple Japanese dishes using ingredients found in every Western kitchen. Learn to identify and make the same things you see in all your favorite manga: authentic onigiri (rice balls), yakitori (skewered chicken), oshinko (pickled vegetables), udon (Japanese noodles), okonomiyaki (Japanese-style pizza) and many others! Includes sections on how to assemble bento boxed lunches and properly use chopsticks. Features original manga illustrations by Chihiro Hattori."

132.heading: Japanese Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Miscellanea.

132.author: by Christine Rook
132.appears_in: p. 1D, 6D in The Lansing State Journal, Feb. 27, 2003.
notes: "Today's teens aren't satisfied with just reading and watching Japanese-style animation; they're creating their own art."
Shows local artists Amanda Diamond and Christ Hill, and quotes comics retailer Stephen Jahner and art teacher Shavaughn Simon.
